settings.text: Brain and spinal cord injuries can have devastating long-term effects. From changes in mobility to cognitive impairments, injuries to this area of the body can often change a personâ€™s outlook on their life. Unfortunately, these types of trauma are common. In fact, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, there are around 17,000 deaths from traumatic brain injuries each year and approximately 12,500 deaths from spinal cord injury annually. While rehabilitation and support programs exist to help those affected manage their condition, treatments may still be limited due to the serious nature of the injury. It is therefore important that we continue striving for better prevention and treatment strategies for those who suffer from brain or spinal cord trauma. settings.heading: What are the main symptoms for Brain and Spinal Cord Injury?

settings.text:
There are many different symptoms that can be brought on by brain and spinal cord injuries, and they may start out suddenly or worsen over time. The most typical signs are as follows:

-A loss of motion
-Sensation loss
-Paralysis alterations in vision
-Variations in hearing
-Changes in flavor or odor
-Balance or coordination issues
-Difficulty swallowing or speaking
-Changes in attitude or conduct
-Memory issues
-Seizures

Additional symptoms may include the following, depending on the injury's location and seriousness:
- Breathing problems
-Inconsistent heart rate
-Variations in blood pressure
-Profound bruising or bleeding
-Incontinence
-Persistent pain
- Sleep issues
-Fatigue

settings.heading: How damaging are Brain and Spinal Cord injuries?

settings.text: Extremely crippling injuries to the brain and spinal cord frequently result in long-term or permanent disability. Seek immediate medical attention if you or a loved one has experienced a brain or spinal cord injury, and speak with a qualified personal injury lawyer about your legal options.

settings.heading: Brain and Spinal Cord injury causes

settings.text: Brain and spinal cord injuries frequently result from the carelessness or negligence of another person. You might be entitled to financial support for your medical expenses, lost wages, and suffering if you were hurt in an accident that wasn't your fault. You can get the compensation you are entitled to with the help of an experienced personal injury lawyer.

settings.heading: How to prevent a Brain and Spinal Cord Injury?

settings.text:
A brain or spinal cord injury cannot be totally avoided. You can nevertheless take the following actions to lower your risk:

-Always buckle up when you get into a vehicle.
-Avoid texting and driving.
-Be on the lookout when engaging in contact sports.
-Always wear a helmet when skating, rollerblading, or riding a bike.
-Steer clear of diving into shallow water.
-Be cautious when engaging in any activities that could cause a fall, such as climbing trees.
